Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:The Effect of Outer Rainband Heating and Cooling on Hurricane Intensity

POR.DRECONTENT:
The differences between tropical clouds in general and tropical cyclone (i.e., TC or hurricane) clouds in particular have never been fully described. Considering the large impact of hurricanes on US coastlines and the difficulty models have in predicting hurricane intensity change, we deemed it important to understand how and why hurricane clouds are unique. Only by understanding the nature and structure of hurricane clouds can we determine their role in hurricane intensification. I chose to do this research with Dr Yukari N. Takayabu at Tokyo University because of her extensive knowledge of the tropical atmosphere and the capabilities of her institution. The data used in this study is from the Tropical Rain Measuring Mission’s (TRMM) Precipitation Radar. This radar was the first to provide a three dimensional view of rainfall from space.

 

Using data from 1998-2007 over the West Pacific (which viewed over 200 hurricanes), we found that precipitating hurricane clouds are much more prevalent from 5-10km height than are precipitating clouds in the general West Pacific (Figure 1). This is thought to be due to an enhanced melting layer around 5km in hurricane environments. Melting, as it’s an endothermic process, leads to localized cooling. As hurricanes have heightened levels of ice, the melting of this ice leads to a cooler layer around the melting level which causes more clouds to form at that height. The reason why hurricane environments have heightened cloud amounts all the way to 10km remains a mystery. While hurricanes have more clouds from 5-10km than does the general tropical environment, hurricanes receive more of their rainfall from large precipitating clouds above 12km height (Figure 2). The relative contribution of mid- and low-level rainfall in hurricanes is almost nil, whereas it is quite significant in the general tropics.

 

While the heightened cloudiness was expected in the mid-levels in hurricane environments (compared to the general tropics), the sharp jump in precipitating cloud amount at 5km was a surprise (Figure 3). This feature was also found over small time scales and persisted through each of the years of the study. Going forward, it is important to determine the effect of these precipitating cloud features on hurricane intensification processes and discover the mechanism of the formation of midlevel clouds from 6-10km. Much remains to be learned in terms of how hurricanes intensify. Only by understanding the role of clouds in this process will we be able to one day predict hurricane intensity change with accuracy.
